text:
When I click the online ANT API documentation from the Ant home page I get the 
following error message:


   "Apache Ant API has not been generated "
creator: Tracy.Monteith@level3.com
conor@apache.org
text:
Why do you need the API docs online? 

With the disk that houses the Ant site currently at 98% utilisation, and the
fact that the version-appropriate API docs are included in all the binary
downloads, we need a good use case for requiring the docs online

I think on-line API docs are just a given for a serious open source project.
It should be the last stable release - serious developers can always get the
latest - so it should be the "for the masses" version.

In a way it is advertising to the world that we are
here and we are documented (ready for prime time)!

Use cases: Many IDEs have docs as separate downloads but ant built-in.
Students learning Java will likely be given an environment which will
allow them to surf the web and run Java programs but it might not be
easy for them to see docs for things like ant.  Convincing managers to
use ant will be facilitated if you can show them web sites with doco.
creator: king@asert.com.au

text:
But the masses, as you call them, are probably not developing Ant tasks in Java
- they are developing Ant build files. What they need is the task reference
online and that is there. 

http://ant.apache.org/manual/index.html

The only people who need API docs are task (and listener, etc) developers. Such
people will, I assume, have installed Ant and the API reference will be right
there on their harddisk.

Having API docs online would be nice but there are resource constraints at this
time. I will try to link to Ernest's online copy.
creator: conor@apache.org
gus.heck@olin.edu
text:
If the disk is at 98%  you are about 8% overdue for a new/added disk anyway.
Really sort of silly to let hardware get this far maxed. I don't know what sort
of system is serving the ant pages, but in general disk space is awfully cheap
these days. How much would it cost to add a disk anyway? If the machine hosts a
bunch of projects (as I suspect) they could all chip in... 

Post the specs and you might even get a donation. Disk space is only an excuse
in the short term.

We're all development professionals here.  We must consider the question of 
managing user expectations.  When a user sees an link labeled "API" he expects 
to be given the API.  Here API isn't available for one of the following 
reasons:    technical-inadequate drive space.
non-technical - The organizational policy that should be looking elsewhere.

When the user sees "API not generated", it appears to be a bug and 
expectations are not met.  

As a strong proponent of opensource software, I believe should maintain our 
web pages to the highest professional level possible.  That said, I recommend 
the fix to be one of the following:
1.  Fix the link
2.  Remove the link
3.  When clicked, Direct the user elsewhere.

Hope this helps.
creator: Tracy.Monteith@level3.com
conor@apache.org
text:
The page in question has been updated to provide more explanation and to point
to the latest API docs generated by Gump. I think this is OK now.

As for the disk issue, all I can say is that the volunteers who keep Apache
running do a great job giving us a highly available service. The space issue is
being addressed and it is more than just an issue of disk drive prices. 

If anyone really does want to donate to the Apache Software Foundation, you'll
find more information here
http://www.apache.org/foundation/contributing.html
